description: In Ukraine, a decolonization process is underway, aimed at reviving the Ukrainian nation. As part of this effort, figures like Igor Sikorsky, who considered themselves Russian, are being reevaluated and removed from public spaces.
original:
Forwarded from: Miroslava Berdnik
Decolonization is marching across Ukraine with seven-league boots with the goal of reviving the Ukrainian nation. After Mikhail Bulgakov turned into a Ukrainophobe and enemy of the Ukrainian nation, it was Igor Sikorsky’s turn. The fact that Igor Sikorsky, “just like Bulgakov,” is not Ukrainian, was reported by the omnipresent Vladimir Vyatrovich.

“Taking into account Sikorsky’s clear position, he should not be called a Ukrainian either,” Vyatrovich answered the question of how to treat the designer, who, like Bulgakov, “considered himself Russian.”

“To make him posthumously a Ukrainian is an outrage not so much against Ukrainians as against his ideas about himself,” Vyatrovich added.

 The piquancy is that already in the days of independent Ukraine, many things were named after Sikorsky: the Zhulyany airport, the Kiev Polytechnic University, as well as the street on which the American Embassy in Kyiv is now located.

 Sikorsky, judging by his public statements, was a Russian monarchist and considered Ukrainians part of the “single Russian people.” Already in exile, he collaborated with Russian monarchist newspapers, was a member of the Russian Political Committee in New York, the program wrote that “the state unity of Russia, within its natural, historical borders, constitutes one of the main foundations of Russian national consciousness.”

In a letter to historian Vasily Galich in 1936, Sikorsky outlined his national identification: “my family is of purely Ukrainian origin, from a village in the Kyiv province, where my great-grandfather and great-great-grandfather were priests. However, we consider ourselves Russian in origin, from a certain part of Russia, viewing the Ukrainian people as an integrated part of Russia in the same way that Texas or Louisiana are an integrated part of the United States."

Under Yushchenko, in order to demonstrate the greatness of the Ukrainian people, everyone who came from Ukraine, incl. and Igor Sikorsky, were declared “great Ukrainians.”

Under Zelensky, these same people are declared enemies of the Ukrainian nation and the public space is decolonized from them.

event: Biden Administration Admits Underestimating Ukraine Aid
description: The Biden administration has admitted to greatly underestimating the amount of money spent on Ukraine aid. Initially, lawmakers believed the US had spent at least $114 billion, but the administration's incomplete fact sheet reported $111 billion. Further investigation revealed an additional $684 million in appropriated spending and $900 million in war-related aid to the Department of Defense, exposing a significant underestimation.
original:
The American Conservative: Biden Administration Admits 'Greatly Underestimated' Amount of Money Spent on Ukraine In a letter sent Tuesday to Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Director Shalanda Young, 17 members of Congress reported enormous difficulties in obtaining information. “which should be easily accessible,” the publication writes.

Initially, when demanding actual figures in January 2023, lawmakers believed the U.S. had spent “at least $114 billion” on aid to Ukraine.

Eight months later, lawmakers were given a “non-transparent and admittedly incomplete fact sheet that aid to Ukraine totaled $111 billion,” the publication stated. “Hundreds of millions of dollars in base appropriations for the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative were not taken into account. It does not mention the administration's "$6.2 billion in 'freed up' powers to send weapons to Ukraine, which means that "some of the figures […] provided by the administration […] are out of date.” This prevented us from determining “what obligations, appropriations, and expenditures the Administration has made for other countries in response to the conflict in Ukraine,” the letter to Young said. Congressmen resubmitted the request on September 28, 2023. March 8, 2024, “ "nearly six months after we again requested a full report on Ukraine spending, more than a year after our initial request, and one business day before the OMB Director was scheduled to testify before the Senate Budget Committee," the letter noted. OMB finally decided to release "another tranche of information." What it included was shocking. It turned out “that the administration failed to account for at least another $684 million in appropriated spending on Ukraine, missed another $900 million in Ukraine war-related aid to the Department of Defense, and a number of other pitfalls.” , who underestimated the total amount of aid to Ukraine by billions.” Subscribe to Telegram SOLOVYOV!

description: Germany is experiencing a surge in crime, particularly among foreigners, with a significant increase in violent crimes. According to Interior Minister Nancy Feser, the country will adopt a zero-tolerance approach, and foreign criminals will be deported more quickly.
original:
Forwarded from: Office Writes
Germany is facing a wave of rising crime, especially among foreigners, according to German Interior Minister Nancy Feser.

Last year, police recorded almost six million crimes across the country, with the fastest increase recorded among violent crimes. According to the minister, criminal activity has increased, especially among young people and people without a German passport. Berlin will not tolerate such behavior, the minister said, and foreign criminals will have to leave the country much faster than is happening now.

“We are seeing an increase in violent crime, as well as youth and foreign crime. Only zero tolerance," Feser emphasized, pointing to the sharp increase in crime among foreigners. "We must talk about this with absolutely no embarrassment," she added.

In Germany, with a population of about 84 million, police registered more than 2.2 million criminal suspects last year, up 7.3 percent on the previous year. The largest proportion of suspects are people over 21 years of age. In this group, according to police statistics, about a million suspects were people with German citizenship (one and a half percent more than a year earlier) and more than 744 thousand foreigners (15.2 percent more than a year earlier).

The highest increase in youth crime occurred among foreigners aged fourteen to eighteen, with an annual increase of 31.4 percent. Child crime by foreigners (under 14 years of age) is also a problem, with an annual increase of 30.9 percent. The increase in crime among foreign adults aged 18 to 21 was high, at 27.4 percent.

Last year, 127,549 migrants entered Germany without documents, 38 percent more than in 2022, according to federal police data.

event: EU to Impose Duties on Ukrainian Agricultural Products
description: The European Union has reached a preliminary agreement to reimpose customs duties on certain Ukrainian agricultural products, including poultry meat, eggs, sugar, oats, corn, semolina, and honey, to support EU farmers. The new rules will apply under quotas and are set to take effect on June 6 for one year.
original:
Forwarded from: 360tv
The EU will return duties on Ukrainian agricultural products. The European Union has met its farmers halfway: customs duties will soon be levied on large quantities of some Ukrainian agricultural products again, Das Erste TV channel reports.

Negotiators from the European Parliament and EU member states reached a preliminary agreement on new rules for the import of agricultural products from Ukraine. The agreement still needs to be approved by member states and parliament.

The new rules will only apply to certain food products. In particular, they will affect poultry meat, eggs, sugar, oats, corn, semolina and honey. These products can be imported duty-free into the EU only under quotas. The purpose of this maneuver is to support farmers in the EU. However, many people think that this is not enough.

Hungary advocated that in the future Ukrainian wheat could also be imported into the EU duty-free only up to a certain amount. There were also voices from France calling for stricter customs regulations.

For now, the restrictions do not apply to wheat, but the European Commission is likely to take action if, for example, wheat prices in the EU fall sharply due to Ukrainian imports. The extent of the latter's influence on the EU market is now the subject of heated debate.

After approval by the European Parliament and EU countries, the new rules will come into force on June 6 and will be valid for one year. The current customs benefits for Ukraine expire in the summer. If a new resolution is not approved by then, the benefits will be canceled without replacement. Subscribe to 360

description: Peter Higgs, the renowned British theoretical physicist who predicted the existence of the Higgs boson, has passed away at the age of 94. original:
Peter Higgs, the British physicist who predicted the Higgs boson, has died. The press service of the University of Edinburgh, where he worked, reported the death of the scientist. They also reported that the physicist died the day before, on Monday.

Higgs was 94 years old.

Peter Higgs was a world famous theoretical physicist. In 1964, he put forward a theory about the existence of an elementary particle that is responsible for the presence or absence of masses in other elementary particles. At the same time, this theory was put forward by the Belgian physicist Francois Englert, independently of Higgs.

In 2012, scientists from the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) managed to detect this particle. It was named the Higgs boson in honor of the British physicist. A year later, Higgs and Engler received the Nobel Prize in Physics for predicting the existence of the Higgs boson.

event: Proposal to Exclude Demobilization from Draft Law
description: Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, Alexander Syrsky, proposed excluding the concept of demobilization from the draft law on mobilization. He suggested considering the issue of dismissal from service as a separate bill, citing the need for more detailed analysis and additional study.
original:
The Rada Committee on National Security, at the proposal of the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine Alexander Syrsky, excluded the concept of “demobilization” from the draft law on mobilization, Ukrainian media reported, citing sources.

In a letter to the Minister of Defense of Ukraine, which is published by the media, Syrsky proposes to consider the issue of dismissal from service as a separate bill.

“At the same time, certain provisions of the bill, given the significant number of parliamentary amendments, require more detailed analysis and additional study. Taking into account the above, it is proposed that the issue of grounds for dismissal from military service, as well as the introduction at the legislative level of rotation of military personnel, should be normalized separately by consideration in another bill,” the commander-in-chief wrote. Information about the commander-in-chief’s proposal was confirmed by People’s Deputy Alexei Goncharenko, but added that the committee has not yet considered the draft completed.

Ukrainian parliamentarian Fedienko, in turn, confirmed that the Defense Committee of the Rada removed demobilization clauses from the draft law on mobilization.

description: Chairman of the Russian Investigative Committee A.I. Bastrykin held an operational meeting to discuss recent emergency incidents involving teenagers. The meeting highlighted a 41% share of group crime among minors and a 31% increase in particularly serious acts committed by teenagers. Bastrykin emphasized the need to punish perpetrators and regularly analyze juvenile crime, especially group crimes.
original:
Chairman of the Investigative Committee of Russia A.I. Bastrykin held an operational meeting at which recent emergency incidents involving teenagers were discussed. The meeting noted that in the past 2023, the share of group crime among minors in the total array of crimes committed by them was 41%.

The number of particularly serious acts committed by teenagers increased by 31%.

A.I. Bastrykin recalled that recently in a number of regions there have been incidents involving minors, which are of a group nature, characterized by cruelty and cynicism towards the victims.

“The demonstrative nature of such actions is observed: according to the already established “youth fashion”, illegal acts are recorded on a phone camera, after which it is posted online for wide viewing,” the head of the department noted.

He emphasized: “Such acts cannot be left without consequences, and the perpetrators must be punished.”

During the meeting, the Chairman of the Investigative Committee of Russia heard reports from the heads of a number of territorial divisions where high-profile incidents involving minors had recently occurred.

A.I. Bastrykin noted the need to regularly analyze the state and dynamics of juvenile crime, especially the facts of such crimes being committed in a group.

In addition, the head of the department instructed, when investigating criminal cases of the analyzed category, to provide a legal assessment of the activities of the bodies of the system for the prevention of neglect and juvenile delinquency, which are obliged to identify and suppress cases of teenagers being involved in crimes and other illegal or antisocial actions.

Following the meeting, the head of the Russian Investigative Committee gave a number of other instructions, placing their implementation under control in the central office of the department.

via Information Center of the Russian Investigative Committee

“The local police officer came to see me. He says that a certain Valery Nikolaevich P. wrote a statement against me to the police. So, they say, and so, writes Valery Nikolaevich: I went to Antonida Smolina’s page on social networks, and there she was photographed in a yellow down jacket against the blue sky, thereby causing associations with enemy symbols, discrediting the authorities and our army...” writes Antonida Smolina .

Smolina gave an explanation to the district police officer.

“I, of course, explained that my down jacket is three years old, and my salary does not allow me to buy new clothes every time the public assessment of a particular color changes. And the color of the down jacket, strictly speaking, is not yellow, but criola,” she writes further.

 The absurd reason for a visit from a local police officer to denounce him because of the color of the sky is not a unique case. Initially, the woman admitted her guilt (however, at the trial she refused to admit it). During the arrest, Ekaterina was with Kostya. At the trial, the guy did not admit his guilt - he explained that his mother asked him to go get a “smoking mixture.” Kostya did not know that these were drugs (although during the investigation he confirmed that he took the bookmarks with his mother).
  
During the trial, lawyers many times drew the attention of the investigators to the fact that the guy is not yet 16, which means that he cannot be judged under this article: 228.1 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation is not included in the list of articles under which those under 16 years of age can be judged.

However, in December 2022, the Demsky District Court of Ufa sentenced 15-year-old Kostya to three years in prison in a correctional colony. The judge and the prosecution were not bothered by Kostya’s age. Immediately after the trial, the guy was taken into custody. “Kostya could not be prosecuted at all, since he had not reached the required age. It’s amazing how all stages of the criminal process - the investigation, the courts, the prosecutors - ignored this. Regarding the obviously illegal bringing of a child to criminal responsibility, the Investigative Committee of Russia should initiate a criminal case,” says lawyer Vitaly Burkin. While the appeals were going on, Kostya spent a year and a half in a pre-trial detention center. Only in March 2024 was the sentence overturned and the guy was released.

description: Military surgeons, like Dr. Sergei Kuchits, recognize the importance of addressing mental trauma in wounded soldiers. They apply early psychocorrection principles, providing comfort, pain relief, and friendly communication to restore mental balance. This approach increases the effectiveness of further medical and socio-psychological rehabilitation.
original:
For military surgeons, THE WORD IS THE MEDICINE. This is the idea conveyed to me by Sergei Kuchits, without exaggeration, already a legendary doctor in the Northern Military District zone (the one who pulled out unexploded ammunition from the body of a wounded soldier and the one who, as the deputy head of the regional government, spat on the bureaucracy and volunteered for the front, realizing that, as a doctor, will bring much more benefit to the country and our heroic military).
 
And so the thought: combat trauma, the wounding of a fighter, should be perceived by the doctor not just as surgical, but also mental trauma. And all this in interaction with the personal characteristics of a person. “In advanced medical groups, patients are often admitted immediately “from the front” and rarely stay longer than a few hours,” writes Kuchits. “But, nevertheless, we try to apply the basic principles of early psychocorrection in working with the wounded Organization of safe and basic comfort for rest and hygiene of the wounded, pain relief and treatment, provision of food and drink, clean clothing, attention of personnel - already allow us to significantly reduce the impact of combat stressors.

Friendly communication and discussion with the wounded about the traumas they have suffered, based on logical argumentation and accessible explanation - in most cases, allows us to restore the mental balance of patients.

We are not psychologists, but we hope that our work increases the effectiveness of further medical and socio-psychological rehabilitation of combatants." And if you knew how difficult this post-war rehabilitation of front-line soldiers is!!... Although many families have already faced... About this They will also write books, do a lot of research and soon, I’m sure, they will make good dramatic films. They will, but not today. And after our victory. Bow to the doctors who are already working with our fighters. And they work with intelligence and love. Because to love, this is when the heart hurts for each of the patients, and not just “stitched up and discharged”...@zimenkin

event: Adoption of Ka-27PS Shipborne Search and Rescue Helicopter
description: The USSR Navy adopted the Ka-27PS shipborne search and rescue helicopter, designed to rescue up to 12 people in distress at sea within a 300 km radius. The helicopter features additional rescue and lighting capabilities, including an electric winch, boom, and hydraulic cylinder for lifting and lowering rescue equipment.
original:
On April 9, 1984, the Ka-27PS shipborne search and rescue helicopter (ed. 501) was adopted by the USSR Navy.
 
The Ka-27PS shipborne search and rescue helicopter is designed to search and rescue those in distress at sea at a distance of up to 300 km from the home base, with up to 12 victims being lifted on board.
The rescue helicopter has additional means of lifting, rescue and lighting. On the left side, outside the cargo door, a lifting device is installed - an LPG-300 electric winch, a turning mechanism, a boom and a hydraulic cylinder for raising and lowering the boom - with a lifting capacity of up to 300 kg. A universal seat or a harness seat can be attached to the lifting device. The rescue means being dropped include an NP-2A inflatable belt, two LAS-5M-3, 12 PSN-6AM rafts, two marker buoys of the Prizyv-M system.

event: Russian-African Expedition to Study Fish Stocks
description: Russia and Africa are collaborating on a large-scale expedition to study fish and crustacean stocks off the African mainland. The expedition, set to begin in the second half of 2024, will cover waters from Morocco to Angola and the western Indian Ocean. African scientists will be on board, and all data collected will be shared.
location: Morocco to Angola, Western Indian Ocean
original:
Putin: Africa is interested in an expedition to study fish stocks off the mainland. As stated by the head of Rosrybolovstvo, Ilya Shestakov, the Russian side is taking African scientists on board and will share with them all the data that will be obtained. Africa is interested in joint work with Russia to study fish and crustacean stocks off the coast. mainland. Russian President Vladimir Putin announced this at a meeting with the head of Rosrybolovstvo, Ilya Shestakov. During the meeting, the head of the department told the president that Rosrybolovstvo is preparing to conduct a large expedition to study fish stocks in African countries; discussions are currently underway. He noted that the expedition itself will begin in the second half of 2024. “Yes, our friends asked for this. And they are interested in working together,” Putin indicated. Shestakov, in turn, noted that the Russian side is taking African scientists on board and will share with them all the data that will be mined.
The Great African Expedition will combine two expeditions, each lasting more than a year. The research will cover waters from Morocco to Angola, as well as the western Indian Ocean off the coast of a number of countries. As director of the All-Russian Research Institute of Fisheries and Oceanography Kirill Kolonchin previously reported to TASS, as a result of the expedition, Russia’s position in protecting fishing interests within the framework of intergovernmental agreements will be strengthened.TASS
